hero.title: NYC Subway Safety Guide for Solo Travelers
hero.subtitle: A practical, scenario‑driven guide to navigating NYC’s subway confidently and safely.

why_trust_this_guide.author_expertise: Built using NYC transit data, rider behavior patterns, and real-world solo traveler insights.
why_trust_this_guide.local_insights: Neighborhood-specific notes based on station layout, foot traffic, and time-of-day patterns.
why_trust_this_guide.safety_framework: Structured using cognitive load reduction, progressive disclosure, and scenario-based learning.
why_trust_this_guide.editorial_standards: Fact-checked, persona-driven, and updated regularly for accuracy.

core_principles.title: Stay Aware, Not Afraid
core_principles.description: Confidence comes from understanding your surroundings and making deliberate choices.

core_principles.title: Position Yourself Strategically
core_principles.description: Choose well-lit areas, stand near other riders, and avoid isolated corners.

core_principles.title: Trust Your Instincts
core_principles.description: If something feels off, move cars, change platforms, or exit the station.

core_principles.title: Minimize Exposure to Risk
core_principles.description: Avoid empty cars, late-night transfers, and poorly lit exits.

core_principles.title: Use Tools That Give You Control
core_principles.description: Apps, alerts, and maps help you stay ahead of delays and disruptions.

subway_basics.how_the_system_works: The subway is the city’s heartbeat — running 24/7 and threading 472 stations across four boroughs. Trains move fast, signs move faster, and everything clicks once you learn the rhythm.

peak_vs_off_peak.peak: 7–10 AM and 4–7 PM — crowded, loud, and full of motion. The rush can feel chaotic, but the constant foot traffic adds a layer of safety.
peak_vs_off_peak.off_peak: Late nights and early mornings — quieter platforms, longer waits, and fewer riders. The city exhales, and you stay a little more aware.

subway_basics.fare_basics: Tap with OMNY or swipe a MetroCard. One fare covers one ride, and transfers within two hours are free. OMNY tracks your rides automatically so you never overpay.
subway_basics.station_layouts: Stations are mini‑mazes with multiple entrances, mezzanines, and exits that lead to very different streets. Follow the signs, and when unsure, choose the exit with more light and foot traffic.
subway_basics.train_types: Local trains stop everywhere. Express trains fly past smaller stations and cover long distances fast — great when you’re headed far, but easy to miss if you’re not watching the signs.

platform_etiquette: Stand behind the yellow line at all times
Let riders exit fully before you step in
Form loose lines instead of crowding the doors
Keep backpacks and bags close to your body
Avoid standing at the platform edge while distracted
train_etiquette: Keep bags in front of you, not on your shoulder
Don’t block doors — move into the car quickly
Offer priority seats to seniors, pregnant riders, and people with disabilities
Keep music and phone volume low
rush_hour_rules: Expect heavy crowds and limited personal space
Move to the center of the car instead of hovering near doors
Remove backpacks and hold them low
Step aside quickly when the train arrives
unspoken_norms: Minimal eye contact — it’s normal, not rude
Avoid staring, pointing, or reacting loudly
Don’t take up extra seats or spread out
Respect personal space even when crowded

faq.question: Is the NYC subway safe at night
faq.answer: Yes, with precautions — ride in busier cars and avoid isolated stations.

faq.question: Which lines are safest
faq.answer: Lines with high commuter traffic like 1/2/3, A/C/E, and N/Q/R/W.

faq.question: How do I avoid empty cars
faq.answer: Look for cars with riders and avoid unusually empty ones during busy times.
